It should be true that the higher you are, the lower the required velocity to orbit.
Consider the way the orbit works: gravity tries to pull you down to the planet, but because of your tangential velocity, you miss the planet and thus orbit it. The tangential velocity has to be such that it allows you to cover enough tangential distance before you reach the planet, so that you can miss the planet.
The larger the force, the faster you fall. And if you are falling faster, it means you have less time to move out of the way of the planet. Therefore, you need a larger tangential velocity. Furthermore, the closer you are to the planet, the less distance you need to travel to get to it, which means that you again have less time to move out of the way.
Turning the statement on the head shows that the tangential velocity should be smaller the further away you are from the planet because not only is there more distance to cover to get to the planet, the gravitational force weakens as you get away.
However, if you were to compare the velocity needed to reach two different orbits, you'd require a larger velocity to reach the larger orbit. That's because the Earth's gravity would slow you down as you move towards your orbit, so you need a larger initial velocity to get there. The velocity you'd actually need to orbit is smaller for the larger orbit though.

The value of potential energy is arbitrary, so asking whether it has a specific value at a certain point doesn't really mean anything. That being said, I kind of get the question because I had the same question myself before: what is the significance of zero force?
As you already mentioned, zero force means a maximum or minimum for the potential. This means that if you moved a little bit from where you are, you wouldn't gain much kinetic energy: your speed doesn't change much. If the potential energy is a maximum, this doesn't last long: your KE and speed snowballs, and hence a maximum potential is very unstable. The slightest disturbance could get you to move. If the forces grow larger as you move away in either direction (down a hill for example), the potential energy was a maximum. If the forces get smaller on either side (up a trough for example), it's a minimum and you'll need a large push to get away. You would be very stable in such conditions.
An example of such a situation is the point between two protons. There is no force at the midpoint because either proton will repel a test charge there with the same force. Yet, if you imagined yourself bringing the test charge from infinity, you'd see that you'd have to push the test charge hardest to bring it to the midpoint. Thus it has the highest potential energy possible there. If you moved the test charge a little bit to the right or the left, there would be a very small force at first, but as it pushes the test charge, the force would get progressively stronger and stronger. There would be no going back to the midpoint.

The quantity T/r' is the derivative of the kinetic energy with respect to the velocity. r' = dr/dt, where r is the position. (Keep in mind that when I say position, velocity etc... I really mean it for generalised coordinates. So r could be the angle and r' could be angular velocity if the situation calls for it. I'm just using the usual terms for simplicity). So you could define a v = dr/dt then rewrite it as T/v. It's just clearer with r'. d/dt(T/r') means differentiate T with respect to r', then differentiate that with respect to time.
An example: suppose T = 1/2mv^2, and r is the position. Then r' = dr/dt = v, so T/r' = mv.
d/dt(T/r') would then be mdv/dt (assuming mass is constant).
To derive the expression requires some knowledge of the calculus of variations.
There is a principle in physics, called the principle of least action which states that there is a quantity called the action: S = Ldt (from t_0 to t_1) (L is the Lagrangian, t_0 is the initial time and t_1 is the final time), and that for any system, the action will be a stationary point. That is the action is either a maximum, or a minimum (hence least action. A little of a misnomer because the action is just a stationary point, not always least), or a stationary inflection point. Don't ask me why - I have no idea of why it works.
The laws of physics can then be written in this form: you take an action, and try to optimise it and the laws of physics will pop out from there. The Lagrangian is a function; when you get the correct form for the function, you optimise the action. Therefore this is not a classical optimisation problem; in a classical one you are trying to optimise a function with respect to a variable's value. Here you are trying to optimise a function with respect to the form of a function. Functions whose value depends on the form of another function are called functionals.
How then to proceed? Well, the idea behind df/dx = 0 at a stationary point in classical optimisation is that if you changed X (X is the value such that f(X) = optimum.) by a very small amount, there is practically no change in f. We can use this idea: for the right Lagrangian, if we change our quantities a little bit, a variation in them, we find that the change in S is zero to the first order expansion (there is no change in the linear approximation of S, which is the first two terms of it's Taylor expansion). When we apply this idea, we get this equation:
d/dt (L/r') = L/r
this is called the Euler-Lagrange equations. The post is too long, so I won't post the exact derivation. The Wikipedia article called Hamilton's principle (the principle is just that of least action) has a nice derivation. The Feynman lectures Volume II chapter 19(If I remember correctly. It was called "A special lecture) or so gives a better explanation of the logic behind.
Now for the derivation of your equation.
It turns out that in classical physics, the Lagrangian that satisfies the above equation is of the form T - U, where T is the kinetic energy and U is the potential energy. Of course, all is in generalised coordinates.
So you can plug that in the Euler-Lagrange equation above:
d/dt((T - U)/r') = (T - U)/r.
In general potential energy does not depend on the (generalised) velocity of the object. If you make this assumption the above becomes:
d/dt(T/r') = T/r - U/r
where I split the right hand side. Then you can look at the definition of potential energy mathematically: potential energy is defined such that the negative derivative of the energy with respect to a coordinate gives the force in that direction:
-U/r = F, by definition of U.
So for example, if r represents the position on the x-axis, then the derivative of U with respect to r gives the force in the x-direction. If r is a generalised coordinate, then F would be the generalised force.
If you apply that to the previous equation, you get:
d/dt(T/r') = T/r + F
Move the T/r to the left to get the equation. Everything is in generalised coordinates.
So the idea behind the equation is that there is this quantity called the action, and that any physical system will always have an optimum action, be it a minimum, maximum, or stationary point of inflection. Then from there, with the proper Lagrangian you get this equation. Why it works I have no idea.
A few post-scriptum notes:
-The Lagrangian, by definition, is a function of r, r' and t. When you vary the Lagrangian to derive the Euler-Lagrange equations, what you are doing is changing r by dr and so on. This corresponds to looking at a path that is very close to the real one. For instance, if your path is a straight line, by varying L, you are calculating the action for a path that could have a very, very slight curvature.
-The principle of least action surprisingly works for any kind of physics provided you tweak the Lagrangian. For instance in relative, the Lagrangian is -mc^2/y where y is the gamma factor and c is the speed of light.
-There is another derivation of your equation, using the principle of virtual work and its extension, the d'Alembert principle. The principle of virtual work basically says that if you have a system where everything is stationary, and the net force is zero, you can imagine a small displacement dr in things in the system, such that dr is physically possible (solids can't go through solids for example) and that the system is in static equilibrium afterwards. This is a "virtual" displacement, and for this displacement the work done, the "virtual" work will be zero. This makes sense: for something to move from static equilibrium to static equilibrium, no work must have been done on it. D'Alembert's principle says the same thing, but it says that if there are forces in the system, you can move to a non-inertial frame so that there seems to be no force in the system, and the principle will hold. Goldstein's classical mechanics details it. Feynman lectures Volume I chapter 4 talks about virtual work.
-If you are interested in learning more about Lagrangian formalism, Landau and Lifshitz textbooks on physics are excellent for that. I can't find the link right now, but there were posted somewhere on Reddit. Either way it is on archive.org.

They have the same frequency because the force is proportional to the horizontal distance away from the vertical, by Hooke's law.
Whatever factor you multiply this horizontal distance by, you multiply the force by the same factor. Say you double that horizontal distance: you have twice the distance, but also twice the force and thus twice the acceleration. The net result is that you take the same time to cover that distance, so the oscillation rate remains the same.
The horizontal distance is related to the length of the string and the angle from the vertical by trigonometry: x = L sin . So if you change the angle, you are changing x, and thus changing F as well by the same factor. Then the acceleration changes by the same factor so the time taken is constant.
Another way to see this is by considering energy. You could double the height of the pendulum by changing the angle and thus double its energy. Then this energy is converted into kinetic energy. Doubling the kinetic energy corresponds to multiplying the velocity by a factor of 2. The work done is doubled, because kinetic energy = work done, and since work done = force times distance, and by Hooke's law F = kx, both the force and x must be multiplied by 2. Therefore, the power is also multiplied by 2 (force times velocity = power). If the work done and the power are both multiplied by 2, then the time over which energy is transferred, the period must be the same. Therefore, the two pendulums must have the same period.

As an aside I can try giving a crash course on multivariable calculus and integration by parts.
Basically the whole idea of integration by parts is to reverse the product rule. Lets say you have some function U and another V. Then by the product rule:
d(UV) = VdU + UdV.
Now say you have a function UdV and you want to find UdV. Then from the above:
UdV = d(UV) - VdU
UdV = d(UV) - VdU
UdV = UV - VdU and that's the general idea. Lets give it a try: say you have 2x sin x and you want to integrate this:
x sin x dx.
You can rewrite sin x dx as d(-cos x) because the derivative of - cos x is sin x. Then if you rewrite your function:
x d(- cos x) which is of the form UdV where U = x and V = - cos x.
Therefore UV = -xcos x. Then we need dU. Since U = x dU = dx. Therefore VdU = - cos x dx, -VdU = cos x dx and -VdU = cos x dx = sin x. Then you sum UV and -VdU to get:
x sin x dx = sin x - x cos x, which is the answer. So you basically reverse the product rule to get the answer. That's the essential idea behind integration by parts. You'll need to apply the general idea of integration by parts more often in the lectures, rather than use it to solve problems as in the example. For instance perhaps you have PdV where P is the pressure and V the volume and you want VdP. You could use integration by parts to find that VdP = d(PV) - PdV. In these cases the product rule can give the answer just as easily.
There is some multivariable calculus involved in the book, but multivariable calculus itself is generally not too hard to follow. The idea is that while one variable changes, the other one remains constant. For instance say you have x^2 + y^2. If x and y aren't related to each other, you could treat y as a constant and differentiate with respect to x to get 2x, or you could treat x as a constant and differentiate with respect to y to get 2y. Because you are only differentiating with respect to one variable its called partial differentiation and is written as f/x if you are differentiating with respect to x and f/y if it is with respect to y.
Now what if you wanted the whole differentiation? Then you'd have to parameterise x and y. That is, you express x and y as two different functions of some parameter t. Then you differentiate with respect to t. This time it's the whole derivative. For instance x could = t^2 and y = t^3. Then df/dt = 4t^3 + 6t^5. Choosing the functions for t depends on how x and y are changing, which you generally are told about. It's similar to parameterising planes, because graphically that's what you are doing. In fact graphically, the function f(x,y) may be represented as a plane, and t would then be the parameter you use to parameterise the plane.
The main idea here is that you can treat each variable as separate if they are not related to each other. If y was related to x, then y would be a function of x and you'd have to apply the chain rule.
Multivariable integration is also used, but he doesn't use it in terms of two variables. For instance some integrals can be written as f(x,y)dxdy, where f is integrated with respect to both x and y. But dxdy = dA where A is the area so you could rewrite f(x,y) as f(A) and then integrate.
Don't let all the talk above put you off. I'm not a great explainer, he is. Either way both concepts are used sparingly in the lectures (except the idea that in multivariable functions, each variable can be treated as constant with respect to other; ie, that d(x + y) can be written as dx + dy), and when he does use them, he tends to go into detail. He actually gives a crash course in vector calculus, imaginary numbers, probability, vector algebra and calculus of variations at different points in the book.
If you feel like you might want to brush up on your calculus skills as well, I suggest the textbook Calculus for the practical man, which is available for download on Gutenberg.org. It probably is available on Archive.org as well. It explains calculus in a very easy to understand way.

I'll try and give an example of what I mean: the gravitational field and its potential. A lot of students seem to have difficulty with the concepts, and that's because of the way the material is presented. There's no focus on the fundamental relationship between fields and potentials, just an equation, which is just as incomprehensible without the proper background.
A field represents the force that a mass would exert, in a sense. A field is actually representative of how a potential changes. In fact the relationship between the two is exactly that of force and potential energy, because of what fields and potentials represent. A potential is therefore a sort of measure of energy, and a field shows the direction in which potential is decreasing.
Let's try the concept: say you have a planet and a rocket leaving from the planet. You are given data about how the potential of that rocket changes with distance from that planet and the mass of the rocket. They ask for the gravitational force x meters away from the planet; a classic question. Because you know that the field is the rate of change of the potential in space, you know that if you find the change in potential you find the force. A change in potential is easy to calculate: the difference in the potentials of the rocket, as seen on the graph. Since field = change in potential per unit distance (change in space), you can calculate the field. From there you can get the force = field times mass.
It's useful to know a bit more than the syllabus to reveal hidden links. The IB syllabus simplifies things too much to make solving their questions easy. Practising past papers is useful too of course, but the point is to use this practise as a test of understanding, not a way of understanding itself.

I'm taking all the three HL.
For physics and chemistry, the best way I found is to learn extra. Go beyond the syllabus; the IB exams are uni-level, but the syllabus doesn't teach you the tricks to answer these questions. Corners are cut to make the syllabus "simpler" but it has the opposite effect instead. While you have enough information in the syllabus to answer the questions, the way the information is presented hides many links that would be useful to you.
Going beyond the syllabus gives you the ability to see those links, and if these links are taught well, you should be able to see the essence of the sciences. Seeing the essence makes working a lot easier, as you can base yourself on your own experience, knowledge and expectations -something known as physical intuition. After all, science describes the world we live in, so you should be able to use what you know from experience. When you go in advanced material, things are made a lot more explicit, a lot clearer; the thought process is demonstrated clearly so you can learn how to use your physical intuition.
Also, chemistry is more or less physics reformulated in a more complicated way that deals more with specifics rather than generalities. Therefore the underlying thought processes are easily found from physics. That is, one can better understand chemistry by learning physics. Some basic QM and EM, and a more in-depth Thermodynamics won't hurt. You'd also need to memorise some names and reactions because of the less general nature of chemistry.
To explain how to learn maths is quite more difficult than explaining how to learn science. In general, the maths syllabus is pretty well contained, because IB obviously put quite the emphasis on its rigour. Therefore, it is not really necessary to learn beyond the syllabus to understand. The premises are also easy enough to follow. In my opinion most of the difficulty comes in finding ways to solve problems.
First, algebraic skills must be top-notch. Equation manipulating should become second nature; logs, powers, trig, fractions ... all of that should be automatic. The best way to achieve this is to learn and understand the rules and logic behind them, and thus form algorithms to plow your way through. That way, if ever there is a difficult instance of problems, you can simply apply your algorithms and get an answer either way. In problems where lateral thinking is required, understanding the logic and rules helps establish an algorithm to follow. This is not only advice for equation manipulating; it applies in general for any topic of maths.
One should also be aware of certain identities, because they save time. It's like playing the piano. Sure you could, each time get your sheet music and read the notes one by one and play. It gives a tune, but is also horrendously slow. It's much better to get the sheet music, read it a few times, practise, and eventually learn to play the tune from memory. In the same way, learning identities (quadratic formula, binomial expansion, trig stuff and permutations and combinations are recommended) allows you to solve problems much quicker. Being aware of identities also shows a pathway to a solution much quicker because then you could have extra information about a given problem, or be able to reduce the problem to a stage where identities become useful.
Because maths can retain its essence even in this diluted form, solving problems is as much of an art as a science. The art resides in turning the problem into a stage where you can apply the science. I can't emphasise how important understanding the concepts is. When you do, you can actually reason and open up a multitude of pathways to make a problem solvable using standard methods. Maths HL is particularly fond of giving problems where there is no way to make standard methods work at first glance. One must learn the skill of shaping problems into a form where you can plug and chug away. This skill comes with reasoning about concepts, and practice.
